bestBHT.bht: After Dorcas had passed away, her body was washed in an upper chamber, as was customary among civilized nations. The disciples of Joppa held hope that Peter, known for his miraculous works, would be able to restore their beloved saint. This act of washing the body before burial represented life in the face of death, providing comfort and hope to the faithful. These circumstances surrounding Dorcas's passing and the disciples' actions lend credibility to the miracle that unfolds.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: to the custom of civilized nations towards the dead.
Albert Barnes: Among most people it has been customary to wash the body before it is buried or burned. They prepared her in the usual manner for interment.
There is no evidence that they expected that Peter would raise her up to life.
Marvin Vincent: Upper chamber. See on ch. Acts 1:13.
John Calvin: These circumstances serve to make the miracle to be believed.
In death itself some visible and of the resurrection might comfort the minds of the godly, and lift them up unto some good hope.
It was requisite that contrary shows should be set against [death], that they might represent life in death.
Philip Schaff: It is the custom in Israel, about the dead and their burial, that when any one is dead, they shut his eyes and wash his body.
Death, the followers of Jesus had now learnt to regard with greater calmness and joy.
The disciples of Joppa hoped much from Peter; they certainly had some dim expectation that the great wonder-working friend of Christ would... be able to restore to them their loved saint.
Archibald T. Robertson: This service was rendered by the women, though Luke has λουσαντες (masculine plural aorist active participle of λουω), a general way of saying 'they washed'."
The interment was not hurried as in Jerusalem (Ananias and Sapphira) and the upper room is where the body was usually placed.
In an upper chamber (εν υπερωιω). See on Acts 1:13. Also in verse Acts 9:39. In that house.
John Gill: This custom still continues, and their usual method is to wash the body with hot water, in which they put dried roses and camomile flowers.
And this was the practice both of the ancient Grecians and Romans, that as soon as ever anyone was dead, the body was immediately washed and anointed.
And certain it is, that the Jewish doctors used to meet in upper rooms, and confer together.

bhtAttempts.bht: According to the custom of the time, after Dorcas had passed away, her body was washed in an upper chamber, which was a common practice among civilized nations. The disciples of Joppa had hope and perhaps a faint expectation that Peter, the great wonder-working friend of Christ, might be able to restore their loved saint. This act of washing the body before burial or cremation was a customary practice, providing comfort to the godly and representing life in the face of death. These circumstances surrounding Dorcas's death and the disciples' actions serve to make the miracle that unfolds more believable.

In accordance with the custom of the time, the body of Dorcas was washed in an upper chamber, as was common among civilized nations. The disciples of Joppa held hope and an expectation that Peter, the miraculous companion of Jesus, might be able to restore their beloved saint. This act of washing the body before burial represented life in the face of death and provided solace to the faithful. These circumstances surrounding Dorcas's passing and the subsequent actions of the disciples lend credibility to the miracle that takes place.

The disciples of Joppa held hope that Peter, known for his miraculous works, would be able to restore their beloved saint. This act of washing the body before burial represented life in the face of death, providing comfort and hope to the faithful. These circumstances surrounding Dorcas's passing and the disciples' actions lend credibility to the miracle that unfolds.

The disciples of Joppa had hope and perhaps a faint expectation that Peter, the great wonder-working friend of Christ, might be able to restore their loved saint. This act of washing the body before burial or cremation was a customary practice, providing comfort to the godly and representing life in the face of death. These circumstances surrounding Dorcas's death and the disciples' actions serve to make the miracle that unfolds more believable.

After Dorcas had passed away, her body was washed in an upper chamber, following the custom of civilized nations. The disciples of Joppa held hope that Peter, the great wonder-working friend of Christ, might restore their beloved saint. Washing the body before burial represented life in the face of death, providing comfort to the faithful. These circumstances surrounding Dorcas's death and the disciples' actions make the subsequent miracle more believable.
